author: Ntsakisi Maswanganyi
title: Reserve Bank concerned about steep wage settlements | Economy
text:
Francois Groepe. Picture: DAILY DISPATCH Related articles SA risks losing its dream to a skewed system Growth focus the remedy for economy biased against jobs STRAIGHT TALK: Beyond lose-lose wage talks In this article Companies and organisations: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union | National Union of Mineworkers STEEP wage settlements that are not accompanied by high productivity will be futile, inflationary and costly to the economy, Reserve Bank deputy governor Francois Groepe warned on Tuesday.
Addressing the Southern African Internal Audit conference, Mr Groepe said the Bank, which raised interest rates in July, was concerned about any price developments in the economy and their effect on inflation.
"If inflation is 5% and wage settlements are 10% and there is no change in labour productivity. Unit labour costs increase by 5%, which detracts from the competitiveness of the economy and ultimately ... one typically would have higher layoffs in the labour market," he said.
His comments coincide with wage talks in the gold mining sector. The National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) and the Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union (Amcu) have asked for above-inflation wage increases in the sector and threatened to go on strike if employers do not meet their demands.
Productivity gains would help SA "accommodate" higher wage settlements and contribute to improving living standards, the deputy governor said.
SA, like many other emerging markets, would continue to be affected by global developments, which necessitated the pursuit of local macroeconomic policies that would reduce vulnerability to developments abroad, Mr Groepe said.
The rand tumbled to a 14-year low last week in line with other emerging-market currencies after the Chinese monetary authorities devalued their currency to boost their economy.
